remarks.para: Set the property to true to be able to use the type-specific filters, otherwise the filters operate on the displayed value.
When using native types in conjunction with a non-standard format or an edit mask that cannot be parsed to a native value, it is possible to lose the edited value when it cannot be parsed.

member.summary: Defines the appearance and behavior of a table window's row header. The row header is a non-editable area on the left edge of a table window that displays information that stays displayed even when a user scrolls horizontally. A typical use of a row header is the display of row numbers.
member.param: The title of the row header column.
The width of the row header in pixels.
The row header attributes.
The column that the row header mirrors. Whatever displays in the row header. If colId is 0, the row header is blank.
member.returns: TRUE if the function succeeds and FALSE if it fails.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Windows.SalTableWindow.PopulateFromXML(PPJ.Runtime.SalString,PPJ.Runtime.SalString,PPJ.Runtime.SalBoolean,PPJ.Runtime.SalBoolean)
member.summary: Clears a table window or grid and then fills new rows with data from an XML document. Optionally uses an XML schema to set attributes in the table.
member.remarks:
After each row of data is populated, this function sends message SAM_XMLRowDone to the table window. If an error occurs during the read, then the data in the table may be incomplete and should not be relied upon.
When is set to true, and if the table window's columns were created at design time, the length of each column's value will be the length assigned at design time.
If the table window or grid has no design-time columns and they are being automatically created during the call to this function, then the length of each column's value will be the length that is specified in the XML schema.
This raises the possibility of truncation, if the value of an element contains more characters than are specified by the design-time length or the XML schema length.
member.param: The name of the XML document file containing data to be used to populate the table.
The name of the XML root node of the table, or the name of the XML node pertaining to a table row. See .

If true, it means that the name specified in is the actual root node of the table, and this function should use the default name "row" as the name of the node for each table row. If false, it means that the name in is actually the name of a row node, and each node found with that name should be processed as a table window or grid row.

Indicates whether to retrieve and use an XML schema for determining data types and attributes. If true, the schema is retrieved. If false, data is written into table window cells with the presumption that the table structure is already correct. Currently, cannot be specified true when is false.
member.returns: True if the function succeeds and FALSE if fails. Some failure conditions, such as an invalid file name or invalid root node name, may cause error message dialogs to be displayed.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Windows.SalTableWindow.CreateColumnsFromSchema(PPJ.Runtime.SalString)
member.summary: Creates columns in the with the given schema.
member.param: The path of the XML file.

member.summary: Adds columns to the with the given XSD schema file.

member.summary: Adds columns to the with the given XDR schema file.
member.param: The XDR schema file.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Windows.SalTableWindow.WriteXMLandSchema(PPJ.Runtime.SalString,PPJ.Runtime.SalNumber)
member.summary: Writes the contents and properties of a table window to an XML file and/or a schema file.
member.remarks: If the table window contains a Date/Time column, and a cell in that column is empty, then no content will be written for that particular XML document node.
member.param: The path and name of the output file. Note that the schema file will have the same name, plus the suffix "_schema".
One of the XML constants(XML_DocAndSchema, XML_Document ,XML_Schema), determining whether to write XML, schema, or both.
member.returns: True if the function succeeds.

member.summary: Writes the contents and properties of a table window to an XML file and/or a schema file.
member.remarks: If the table window contains a Date/Time column, and a cell in that column is empty, then no content will be written for that particular XML document node.
member.param: The path and name of the output file. Note that the schema file will have the same name, plus the suffix "_schema".
One of the XML constants(XML_DocAndSchema, XML_Document, XML_Schema), determining whether to write XML, schema, or both.
A combination of one or more of the row flags. Rows must have these flags on in order to be part of the output to XML.
A combination of one or more of the row flags. Rows must have these flags off in order to be part of the output to XML.
member.returns: True if the function succeeds.

A combination of one or more of the row flags. Rows must have these flags off in order to be part of the output to XML.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Windows.SalTableWindow.SetFocusCell(PPJ.Runtime.SalNumber,System.Windows.Forms.Control,PPJ.Runtime.SalNumber,PPJ.Runtime.SalNumber)
member.summary: Sets the focus to the specified table window cell (row and column). Puts the table window into edit mode and lets the user select a portion of the data in the cell.
member.param: The row that receives the edit focus.
The handle (or name) of the column that receives the edit focus.

The position of the left-most character. When used with nEditMax, this parameter lets the user select a portion of the cell text. nEditMin must be less than or equal to nEditMax. To select all the characters in a cell, specify zero (0) for this parameter and -1 for nEditMax.

The position of the right-most character. When used with nEditMin, this parameter lets the user select a portion of the cell text. nEditMax must be greater than or equal to nEditMin. To select all the characters in a cell, specify -1 for this parameter and zero (0) for nEditMin.

Selects the entire row when clicking on the row header. Need to select col = 0 to remove the focus frame from the cell.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Windows.SalTableWindowBase.OnChildGridWndProc(System.Windows.Forms.NativeWindow,C1.Win.C1FlexGrid.C1FlexGrid,System.Windows.Forms.Message@)
member.summary:
Receives all the Windows messages from the inner flexgrid control before they are processed by the grids WndProc.
All the messages are dispatched to the MessageActions handler.
This function returns true if the message is processed and should not be dispatched to the default window procedure.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Com.SalObject.MTSDisableCommit
member.summary: Indicates that the object's transactional updates cannot be committed in the present time until SalMTSEnableCommit() or SalMTSSetComplete() is called. For non-MTS components the SalMTSDisableCommit() will fail (returns false).
member.returns: bOk

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Com.SalObject.MTSEnableCommit
member.summary: Indicates that the objects work is not necessarily done, but that its transactional updates can be committed in their current form (stateful object). EnableCommit is the default state when an object is activated. For non-MTS components the SalMTSEnableCommit() will fail (returns false).
member.returns: bOk

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Com.SalObject.MTSIsInTransaction
member.summary: This method checks if the component is executing in the transaction context. For non-MTS components the SalMTSIsInTransaction() will fail (returns false).
member.returns: bOk

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Com.SalObject.MTSIsCallerInRole(PPJ.Runtime.SalString)
member.summary: Determines whether the caller is in the specified role.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Com.SalObject.MTSIsSecurityEnabled
member.summary: This method checks for the security status. If the object is running in the client's process, there is no security checking and SalMTSIsSecurityEnabled will always return false. For non-MTS components the SalMTSIsSecurityEnabled() will fail (returnS false).
member.returns: bOk

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Com.SalObject.MTSSetAbort
member.summary: Indicates that the objects work can never be committed. The entire transaction is aborted. The object is deactivated upon return from the method. For non-MTS components the SalMTSSetAbort() will fail (returnS false).
member.returns: bOk

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Com.SalObject.MTSSetComplete
member.summary: Indicates that the object has successfully completed its work for the transaction. The object is deactivated upon return from the method that first entered the context (stateless object). For non-MTS components the SalMTSSetComplete() will fail (returns false).
member.returns: bOk

member.name: T:PPJ.Runtime.Sql.SalSqlDataAdapter
member.summary: DataAdapter used to fill the DataSet when result set mode is on. This adapter is safe to use with Oracle numeric columns because it avoids the overflow exception problem when the precision is too big for .NET decimal type.

member.name: T:PPJ.Runtime.Sql.SalSqlDataReader
member.summary:
DataReader wrapper to safely extract Oracle numeric columns without getting the overflow exception when the precision returned by the OCI cannot be stored in .NET decimal type.
Since some ADO.NET driver may pass a null DataReader when executing SQL code that doesn't create a result set we protect against NullObjectReferenceExceptions in our DataReader wrapper.

member.name: P:PPJ.Runtime.Sql.SalSqlDataReader.Provider
member.summary: Returns the original data reader.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sql.SalSqlDataReader.GetOracleOracleValue(System.Int32)
member.summary: Reads the value from the data reader. Avoids the Overflow exception that is generated by Oracle OCI or ODP when the precision exceeds .NET precision. This is a problem in the Oracle drivers.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sql.SalSqlDataReader.GetOracleManagedValue(System.Int32)
member.summary: Reads the value from the data reader. Avoids the Overflow exception that is generated by Oracle OCI or ODP when the precision exceeds .NET precision. This is a problem in the Oracle drivers.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sql.SalSqlDataReader.GetMicrosoftOracleValue(System.Int32)
member.summary: Reads the value from the data reader. Avoids the Overflow exception that is generated by Oracle OCI when the precision exceeds .NET precision. This is a problem in the Oracle drivers.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sql.SalSqlDataReader.GetSqlServerValue(System.Int32)
member.summary: Reads the value from the data reader. Avoids the Overflow exception that is generated by the SqlServer ADO.NET driver when the precision exceeds .NET precision.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sql.SalSqlDataReader.GetSqlBaseFieldType(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the data type of the indicated field. This fixes a bug in Unify/Gupta ADO.NET driver returning float for @IF expressions.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sql.SalSqlDataReader.GetSqlBaseValue(System.Int32)
member.summary: Reads the value from the data reader. Fixes a bug with the Gupta/Unify SqlBase ADO.NET driver when reading DateTime values. The driver doesn't return milliseconds.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sql.SalSqlSessionHandle.CreateStatement(PPJ.Runtime.Sql.SalSqlHandle@)
member.summary: This call creates a new statement belonging to the specified session. The Sql Handle parameter specified here is the same as what the current SqlConnect call returns. There can be any number of statements within a session; there is no limit on this number. This call returns a statement handle if the call was successful. To free a statement, the existing SqlDisconnect call needs to be used.
member.param: The Sql handle used to associate any number of statements to a session.
member.returns: bool

member.name: F:PPJ.Runtime.Sql.Sql.IsolationLevel
member.summary: This system variable sets the isolation level for the next connection to a database server. The isolation level controls the effect that changes made by one user have on another user accessing the same tables. Valid strings are: - Read Repeatability (RR) - Cursor Stability (CS) - Release Locks (RL)

member.name: T:PPJ.Runtime.Sql.SqlContext
member.summary:
Defines a sql context block. This class is used in a using(new SqlContext()) code block to delimit a local context.
The constructor can take the reference to the local variables encapsulating class and to the current object. Both references are used by the interpreter to evaluate bind variables.

member.summary: Constructs a new empty SqlContext.

member.summary: Duplicates a saved SqlContext and pushes it on the stack.

member.summary: Creates a new SqlContext and pushes it on the stack.

member.summary: Creates a new SqlContext and pushes it on the stack.

member.summary: Initializes the SqlContext instance.

member.summary: Ensures that the stack is created and has at least one element in it.

member.summary: Pushes the current context to the stack.

member.summary: Removes the last context from the stack.

member.summary: Returns the local variables instance.

member.name: P:PPJ.Runtime.Sql.SqlContext.Container
member.summary: Returns the container instance.

member.summary: Returns true if the SqlContext has been disposed of (out of scope).

member.name: P:PPJ.Runtime.Sql.SqlContext.Current

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sql.SqlContext.CreateTempContext(System.Object)
member.summary: Creates an temporary instance of SqlContext that keeps a reference to the current SqlContext and uses the specified container reference. When the saved SqlContext reference holding the locals goes out of scope also the locals in the temporary SqlContext created by this method are cleared.

member.summary: Compares two SqlContext instances that may wrap the same locals and container references.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sql.SqlOra.PLSQLPrepare(PPJ.Runtime.Sql.SalSqlHandle,System.String)
member.summary: This function compiles the anonymous PL/SQL block. This function looks very much like the regular SqlPrepare function, but the underlying code is meant specifically for handling Oracle PL/SQL blocks.
member.param: A handle that identifies a database connection.
The actual anonymous PL/SQL block that the user wants to prepare. That will also contain the input and output variables.
member.returns: bOk

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sql.SqlOra.PLSQLExecute(PPJ.Runtime.Sql.SalSqlHandle)
member.summary: This function executes the anonymous PL/SQL block that was prepared using SqlOraPLSQLPrepare. If the execution succeeds, then all output parameters from the PL/SQL block are updated by the time the control returns to the user.
member.param: The sql handle associated with the prepared Anonymous PL/SQL block.
member.returns: Boolean

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sql.SqlOra.PLSQLCommand(PPJ.Runtime.Sql.SalSqlHandle,System.String)
member.summary: Executes an Oracle PL/SQL stored procedure. The first parameter identifies the SQL handle to the database. The second parameter is a command string used to invoke a PL/SQL stored procedure. For some strange reason, PLSQLCommand bind vars don't use the colon delimiter, so we need to parse the bind vars, add the delimiter and reassemble the string.

member.name: T:PPJ.Runtime.Sql.WhenSqlError
member.summary:
This class is use to enclose a When SqlError block in a using(new WhenSqlError()) block. On entering the block a counter is increased, when exiting the block the counter is decreased.
When the counter is zero and a sql error occurs, the Sql implementation will try to use the global error handler. If the counter is non-zero the implementation does not call the global handler.
If this is block omitted, the implementation will alway try to call the global Sql Error handler. If the global handler is not defined, the behavior of the application is unaltered.

member.summary: Dispose WhenSqlError

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sal.Abort(PPJ.Runtime.SalNumber)
member.summary: Halts processing of the current menu action, message action, or application action.
member.remarks: Use this function when you want to terminate the current calling sequence without returning a status. For example, if your application is several layers into internal function calls and an error occurs, this will terminate the current calling sequence of functions and leaves the application in the state it was prior to the first function call of that sequence.
member.param: The status of the exit performed by Abort(). Not used.
member.returns: AbortException

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sal.AppDisable
member.summary: Disables input to all open forms.
member.remarks: Use and when there are multiple applications running simultaneously and you want to control which application receives user input.
member.returns: true if the function succeeds and false if it fails.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sal.AppEnable
member.summary: Enables input to all open forms that were disabled.
member.remarks: Use and when there are multiple applications running simultaneously and you want to control which application receives user input.
member.returns: true if the function succeeds and false if it fails.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sal.AppFind(PPJ.Runtime.SalString,PPJ.Runtime.SalBoolean)
member.summary: Finds a visible top-level window.
member.remarks: If you specify the calling application's name in AppFind(), it can only find another running instance of it. You can use this feature to prevent more than one instance of an application running. If there are multiple instances of a single application, AppFind finds and returns the window handle of the first instance it finds If an application has multiple top-level windows, AppFind returns the handle of the first top-level window it finds. Calling AppFind() multiple times does not always return the handle of the same window. If an application does not have visible windows, then AppFind() cannot find it.
member.param: The name of the application without the extension.
If you set activate to true, AppFind() also activates the application's window.
member.returns: the window

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sal.GetProfileInt(PPJ.Runtime.SalString,PPJ.Runtime.SalString,PPJ.Runtime.SalNumber,PPJ.Runtime.SalString)
member.summary: Retrieves the integer value of an entry in the specified section of an initialization file or registry.
member.param: The section heading.
The entry whose associated value is being retrieved
Specify the default value to return if the function cannot find the entry.
The name of the initialization file or company name depending on the settings made using the function.
member.returns: the integer value of an entry in the specified section of a file or registry, if the function is successful. Returns zero if the value found is not an integer. Returns the default value of the entry if GetProfileInt() cannot find the specified entry.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sal.LoadApp(PPJ.Runtime.SalString,PPJ.Runtime.SalString)
member.summary: Starts an application.
member.remarks: You can start another application by calling LoadApp(). You can use LoadApp() to pass command line arguments from one application to another.
member.param: The name of the application to start.
Optional command line arguments. A space marks the end of one argument and the start of the next.
member.returns: true if the function succeeds. false if the application cannot be found or started.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sal.LoadAppAndWait(PPJ.Runtime.SalString,PPJ.Runtime.SalNumber,PPJ.Runtime.SalNumber@)
member.summary: Starts an application, then waits for it to exit before returning control to the original application.
member.param: The name of the application to start, separated from command line arguments with a space.
The display mode of the application.

The return status. If the function succeeds, retCode is the exit status of the invoked application. A zero exit status usually means successful execution. If the function succeeds, but the invoked application exits before entering a message loop, its exit status is not available. In this case, retCode is zero as though the program exited with a zero exit status. If the function is unsuccessful, retCode is an error code indicating why Windows could not start the application.
member.returns: true if the function succeeds. False if the application cannot be found or started.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sal.LoadAppAndProcessMsgs(PPJ.Runtime.SalString,PPJ.Runtime.SalNumber,PPJ.Runtime.SalNumber@)
member.summary: Starts an application, then waits for it to exit before returning control to the original application. However, the original application can continue to process messages.
member.param: The name of the application to start, separated from command line arguments with a space.
The display mode of the application.

The return status. If the function succeeds, retCode is the exit status of the invoked application. A zero exit status usually means successful execution. If the function succeeds, but the invoked application exits before entering a message loop, its exit status is not available. In this case, retCode is zero as though the program exited with a zero exit status. If the function is unsuccessful, retCode is an error code indicating why Windows could not start the application.
member.returns: true if the function succeeds. False if the application cannot be found or started.

member.returns: true if the function succeeds. False if the function fails.

If the character returned is a 16-bit character, the lead byte of the character is in the high-order byte, and the trail byte is in the low- order byte. To get the lead byte, use SalNumberHigh. To get the trail byte, use SalNumberLow.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sal.FmtKeepMask(PPJ.Runtime.SalBoolean)
member.summary: Turns on/off the flag that indicates whether to keep the mask when reading the text from masked edit controls.
member.remarks: By default, input mask characters are removed when you copy the value in a data field, table window column, or combo box. For example, if you create a data field with the input mask AA-AA and copy its value to another data field, the hyphen is not copied. You can call to change the default behavior so that the input mask characters are kept when you copy the value in a data field, table window column, or combo box. For example, if you create a data field with the input mask AA-AA and copy its value to another data field, the hyphen would be copied. The "^" character in an input mask overrides a setting that you make with this function.
member.param: If false (default), removes input mask characters when you copy a value. If true, keeps the input mask characters when you copy a value.
member.returns: the value that you specified in keep.

member.summary: Defines a named popup menu that displays automatically when a window receives .
member.remarks: For some windows, this function also affects how the window processes a right mouse button click: List box-Right click selects the line under the cursor.If the line is already selected, there is no effect. Combo box-For a combo box where the list is always displayed, the behavior is the same as for a list box. Table window-Right click selects the row under the cursor. If the row is already selected there is no effect.
member.param: Target control on which to execute the call.
A named menu defined in one of the Named Menus section in , 's MDI window parent, or Global Declarations.

member.returns: true if this function succeeds and false otherwise.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sal.CreateWindow(System.Type,System.Windows.Forms.Control,System.Object[])
member.summary: Creates modeless dialog boxes, MDI windows, form windows, and top-level table windows at runtime.
member.remarks: If you specify a parent, the new window always displays on top of its parent, closes when its parent closes, and hides when its parent is minimized. can pass data to and from the window being created by accepting a variable number of parameters. The data types of these parameters must match the parameter data types of the window being created. You can use window parameters to return information from the window being created by using a reference.
member.param: The name of the window to create.
The name of the parent window. Specify if there is no owner window. Note that if you create a top-level form inside a MDI window, then that MDI window will always own the form.
The window parameters.
member.returns: the new window.

member.summary: Creates a form window, dialog box, or table window as a child of another form window, dialog box, or toolbar at runtime.
member.remarks:
If you specify a parent, the new window always displays on top of its parent, closes when its parent closes, and hides when its parent is minimized.
can pass data to and from the window being created by accepting a variable number of parameters. The data types of these parameters must match the parameter data types of the window being created. You can use window parameters to return information from the window being created by using a reference.
member.param: The name of the window to create.
The name of the parent window. Specify if there is no owner window. Note that if you create a top-level form inside a MDI window, then that MDI window will always own the form.
Position of the x-coordinate of the upper-left corner of the window in form units.
Position of the y-coordinate of the upper-left corner of the window in form units.
Width of the window in form units.
Height of the window in form units.

You can combine these flags with the '|' operator.
: Create the window as a child of parent which must be a form, dialog box or tool bar.
: When used with , the window will have a border.
: Create the window, but do not show it.
The window parameters.
member.returns: the new window.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sal.HideWindowAndLabel(System.Windows.Forms.Control)

member.returns: true if the previous state of the window was visible and false if it was hidden. Use this information to hide many windows without first checking that they are visible. When you restore them to their original state at a later point in time, the return lets you make visible only those windows that were previously visible.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sal.IdleKick
member.summary: Simulates an idle state.
member.remarks: Once an idle state is detected, it does not detect another idle state until some messages have appeared in the message queue. Call when you want idle processing to occur even though no messages have been posted. The function is rarely used because idle processing is most often used to detect user input.Since user input causes messages to be posted, an idle state is detected automatically.Usually this function is used when idle processing is needed after another program or a DLL sends a notification message.
member.returns: true if this function succeeds and false otherwise.

Standard message parameter that you can set.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sal.ModalDialog(System.Type,System.Windows.Forms.Control,System.Object[])
member.summary: Creates a modal dialog box.
member.remarks: A modal dialog box suspends the application until the user closes the dialog box. destroys the modal dialog box and enables all windows that were disabled. ModalDialog() can pass information to the dialog box by accepting a variable number of parameters. The data types of these parameters must match the parameter data types of the dialog box being created. You define parameters for the dialog box in the Window Parameters section of the application outline. You can use window parameters to return information from the window being created by using a reference type. Note: Attempting to use the return value from this function to set a Window Handle variable will result in a compile error when compiling to a.NET build target.This function returns a number, not a window handle.
member.param: The type of the modal dialog box to create.
the owner window. Use for a dialog box that does not have an owner.
window parameters
member.returns: the value specified in the second parameter of . Returns -1 if the dialog box is not created.

member.summary: Sets a scroll bar's range, line increment, and page increment.

remarks.para: When the scroll bar is created, it is assigned these values:
Minimum scroll position: 0
Maximum scroll position: 100
Line Increment: 1
Page Increment: 10

If the scroll bar's position before calling this function is outside the range specified by and , its position changes to fall within the new range. and must lie within the range of -32,767 to 32,767.

member.param: Target control (vertical or horizontal scroll bar) on which to execute the call.
The minimum position of the scroll bar.
The maximum position of the scroll bar.
The number of units to increment or decrement the scroll bar when the user clicks the scroll bar arrow.
The number of units to increment or decrement the scroll bar when the user clicks either side of the scroll box.
member.returns: true if the function succeeds and false if it fails.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sal.NavAddGroup(System.Windows.Forms.Control,PPJ.Runtime.SalNumber,PPJ.Runtime.SalNumber,PPJ.Runtime.SalString,PPJ.Runtime.SalNumber)
member.summary: Adds a new group to the specified pane of a navigation bar.

remarks.para: See or for information about the "form unit". If the group is added before an existing group, the group that follows the new group will resize smaller to accommodate the new group. If the new group is appended, the group that immediately precedes the new group will resize smaller. If this does not provide enough space, the next group will be resized as well. For example, if the newly added group (group A) has a height of 200, and the group preceding it (group B) has a height of 100, group B will shrink to a height of 0, and the group that immediately precedes group B (group C) will have its height reduced by 100.

Note: When controls appear above the first defined group separator in a navigation pane, they are categorized as "ungrouped" controls. The controls that appear after the first separator belong to group zero. The controls that appear after the second separator belong to group one. If = 0, the new group will appear immediately above the current group zero, and below any "ungrouped" controls.

member.param: The NavBar control.
Zero-based index of the pane to which you want to add a group.
Zero-based index that the new group will occupy.
The title of the new group.
The height of the new group in form units.
member.returns: true if the function succeeds, false if an error occurs.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sal.TabAttachWindow(System.Windows.Forms.Control,PPJ.Runtime.SalNumber,System.Windows.Forms.Control)
member.summary: Assigns a child window created at runtime to the specified tab page as its container window. You can programmatically create a Form Window or Dialog Box as child and assign it to a tab page by using this function.
member.remarks:
Note:
1. The child window() will resize to fill the tab page, even if is the handle for a single object. If you want several objects on the tab page, use a parent window that contains the desired objects
2. When creating the form or dialog box to associate with the tab, make sure to use the tab bar as the parent window in the call to and/or the nFlag parameter with
3. If a top level window has Accessories Enabled and it was not created with the tab bar it is going to be associated with as the parent, and the call will fail and return
member.param: name of tab control.
Index of a tab page. Start from 0
The child window to assign to specified tab page.
member.returns: the Window to which the child window was previously attached. This function returns if function fails.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sal.MTSCreateInstance(System.Object@)
member.summary: Creates a new component. Depending on the Transaction settings this component will continue the current transaction, will start a new transaction, or will under non-transactional state. For non-MTS components the SalMTSCreateInstance() will work as Create(). Not Implemented-always returns false.
member.param: The requested interface/object to be instantiated.
member.returns: true if the object gets successfully instantiated, otherwise returns false.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sal.MTSDisableCommit
member.summary: Indicates that the object's transactional updates cannot be committed in the present time until SalMTSEnableCommit() or SalMTSSetComplete() is called. For non-MTS components the SalMTSDisableCommit() will fail (returns FALSE).
member.returns: true if successful, returns false if it fails.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sal.MTSEnableCommit
member.summary: Indicates that the objects work is not necessarily done, but that its transactional updates can be committed in their current form (stateful object). EnableCommit is the default state when an object is activated. For non-MTS components the SalMTSEnableCommit() will fail (returns FALSE).
member.returns: true if successful, returns false if it fails.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sal.MTSIsInTransaction(PPJ.Runtime.SalBoolean@)
member.summary: This method checks if the component is executing in the transaction context. For non-MTS components the SalMTSIsInTransaction() will fail (returns FALSE).
member.param: true if the component is executing in the transaction context.
member.returns: Returns true if the component is in a transaction; returns false otherwise.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sal.MTSIsCallerInRole(PPJ.Runtime.SalString,PPJ.Runtime.SalBoolean@)
member.summary: Determines whether the caller is in the specified role.
member.param: The name of the role.
true if the component's caller is a member of the specified role.
member.returns: true if the role specified in is a recognized role and indicates the caller is in that role. Returns false if the role doesn't exist or the call failed.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sal.MTSIsSecurityEnabled(PPJ.Runtime.SalBoolean@)
member.summary: This method checks for the security status. If the object is running in the client's process, there is no security checking and SalMTSIsSecurityEnabled will always return FALSE. For non-MTS components the SalMTSIsSecurityEnabled() will fail (returns FALSE).
member.param: TRUE if the security is enabled
member.returns: true if declarative security is enabled for the component; returns false otherwise.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sal.MTSSetAbort
member.summary: Indicates that the objects work can never be committed. The entire transaction is aborted. The object is deactivated upon return from the method. For non-MTS components the SalMTSSetAbort() will fail (returnS FALSE).
member.returns: true if successful, returns false if it fails.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sal.MTSSetComplete
member.summary: Indicates that the object has successfully completed its work for the transaction. The object is deactivated upon return from the method that first entered the context (stateless object). For non-MTS components the SalMTSSetComplete() will fail (returns FALSE).
member.returns: true if successful, returns false if it fails.

The exponent.

raised to the power, with the following conditions:
1. If is not 0 and is 0, returns 1.
2. If is 0 and is negative, returns to zero(0).

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sal.PrtPrintForm(System.Windows.Forms.Control)
member.summary: Prints a form window, table window, or dialog box, including its contents and row header flags.
member.remarks: If a form window or dialog box contains a child table window, list box or combo box, only the rows on screen print. Lines, frames, and pictures print as well. member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sal.ReportPrint(System.Windows.Forms.Control,PPJ.Runtime.SalString,PPJ.Runtime.SalString,PPJ.Runtime.SalString,PPJ.Runtime.SalNumber,PPJ.Runtime.SalNumber,PPJ.Runtime.SalNumber,PPJ.Runtime.SalNumber,PPJ.Runtime.SalNumber@)
member.summary: Prints a report.
member.remarks: This function is synchronous and does not return until the report has been formatted and sent to Windows or Windows Print Manager for printing. ReportPrint() creates a minimized Report Builder window. A print status dialog box displays while printing. When this function completes, Report Builder automatically ends. Note: This function establishes a dialog between Report Builder and the application; the real work of reporting is in processing the SAM_Report* messages which Report Builder sends. Data is sent from an application to Report Builder when the application returns TRUE in SAM_ReportFetchNext processing. Report Builder continues to send SAM_ReportFetchNext messages until the application returns FALSE.
member.param: The application window that processes SAM_Report* messages.
The report template name.
A comma-separated list of variables from which to fetch data. The data types of these variables must match the data types of the input names in strInputs.
A comma-separated list of the report's input names. The contents of this string are case-sensitive and must match the case of the input names declared in the report template.
The number of copies. If you specify a zero or a negative number, one copy is printed.
You can combine two or more of these constants with the OR (|) operator:
The first page of the report (if includes ).
The last page of the report (if includes ).
If this function succeeds, this parameter is zero. If an error occurs, this parameter is one of the RPT Err* values:
member.returns: The return value is reserved for future use and can be ignored. To detect if the function succeeded, check which is a RPT_Err* value. If successful, is zero. If you want to interact with the report window, interrogate wParam at SAM_ReportStart and save that into the hWndReport variable.

Not used.
You can combine two or more of these constants with the OR (|) operator: Note: and will be accepted but their functionality is irrelevant to ReportPrintToFile() and ReportPrintToFileEx().

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sal.ReportView(System.Windows.Forms.Control,System.Windows.Forms.Control,PPJ.Runtime.SalString,PPJ.Runtime.SalString,PPJ.Runtime.SalString,PPJ.Runtime.SalNumber@)
member.summary: Displays a report in preview mode. Report processing is asynchronous; ReportView() returns after starting the report process.

remarks.para: Note: This function establishes a dialog between Report Builder and the application; the real work of reporting is done in trapping and handling the SAM_Report messages which Report Builder sends.

If you are reporting on application variables, an array, or a file, your data is transmitted to the report only if you return TRUE from the message. Report Builder does not receive any data until it issues the SAM_ReportFetchNext message and the application returns TRUE to that message. Report Builder keeps sending SAM_ReportFetchNext messages until the application returns false.

If there is a print button on the toolbar, and the user clicks it while viewing the report, the sequence of report messages will start again. will not be sent again, but will be. Therefore you must insure that you respond to that message by providing a full set of data, with your application's logic pointed to the beginning of that set. That might mean repositioning a file pointer to the beginning of a file, or preparing a new database result set.

member.param: The name of the application window that processes SAM_Report* messages.
An optional name to a custom report template. If null, Report Builder creates its own window in which it displays the report.
The report template name.
A comma-separated list of variables from which to fetch data. The data types of these variables must match the data types of the input names in .
A comma-separated list of the report's input names.The contents of this string are case-sensitive and must match the case of the input names declared in the report template.

Before you call this function, you can set this parameter to one of the constants below to turn off the printer icon on the default report view tool bar or turn off the tool bar completely: -No print button on the tool bar. -No tool bar in the preview window. If an error occurs, this parameter is one of the RPT Err* constants.
member.returns: the handle of the report window if the function succeeds. The window handle is returned before Report Builder displays the report.

member.summary: Extracts the first character of a string and returns its decimal value.
member.remarks: If DBCS (double-byte character set) is enabled, this number is the integer representation of the 16-bit character. Otherwise the number represents the ASCII value of the 8-bit character. You must use this function in place of if the input string contains DBCS or 16-bit characters. If the character returned is a 16-bit character, the leading byte of the character is in the high-order byte, and the trailing byte of the character is in the low-order byte. Use to get the leading byte and to get the trailing byte.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sal.StrScan(PPJ.Runtime.SalString,PPJ.Runtime.SalString)
member.summary: Returns the offset of a specified substring. If there is more than one instance of the string being searched for, only the offset of the first instance is returned. Case is disregarded in the search.

remarks.para: You can use pattern matching characters. The percent character (%) matches any set of characters. The underscore character (_) matches any single character.

The use of a backslash(\) with SalStrScan differs when searching for a backslash, percent, or underscore character. Its usage also differs depending on whether or not the second parameter is a string literal.
When searching for a backslash and strString2 is a string literal, you need four backslashes:StrScan( 'This is a \\', '\\\\' )
When searching for a percent character or an underscore character and strString2 is a string literal, you need two backslashes: StrScan( 'This is a %', '\\%' ) StrScan( 'This is an _', '\\_' )
Even if is not a string literal, you need a single backslash to search for a percent character or an underscore.

member.param: The string to search. The first character in the string is at offset zero (0).
The string to search for.
member.returns: a number that indicates the offset (0 origin) of in . If is not found in , returns -1.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sal.StrSetBufferLength(PPJ.Runtime.SalString@,PPJ.Runtime.SalNumber)
member.summary: Sets the buffer length of the string to the length plus 1 for the terminator.

remarks.para: Sets the buffer string length to the value in and allocates memory. If is expected to contain a string value rather than binary bytes, be sure to set equal to the expected number of characters plus 1 for the null terminator. This is only needed if you want to pass a Receive String to an external function.

Note that after calling this function, if you subsequently assign a value to the string using an ordinary operation like Set sExample = 'some text', the buffer length of the string will change to match the number of characters assigned, plus one for the null terminator. If you then call an external function that was expecting the original buffer length, you risk the chance of memory corruption through writing text beyond the buffer length.

If a string already has characters assigned to it before you call SalStrSetBufferLength, and you then call the function using a length that is less than the present buffer length, you will truncate the string and lose the null terminator character. This may cause problems when you pass the string to an external function.

member.param: The string whose buffer length you want to set.
The length of
member.returns: true if the function succeeds and false if it fails.

member.returns: true if successful and false if not successful.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sal.StrTokenize(PPJ.Runtime.SalString,PPJ.Runtime.SalString,PPJ.Runtime.SalString,PPJ.Runtime.SalArray{PPJ.Runtime.SalString})
member.summary: Parses a string into substrings (tokens) based on specified start and end delimiters. Delimiters are used to recognize the beginning and end of each substring.

remarks.para: Interprets the first non-start delimiter character as the beginning of a substring, and skips any start delimiters that precede this character. For example, if '!' is a start delimiter, the strings 'Hello' and '!!!Hello' produce the same token: 'Hello'.

If the first non-start delimiter character is an end delimiter character, it is interpreted as a null substring. This is useful for comma-separated data where ',' is an end delimiter. For example, the records 'data1,data2,,data4' and ',data2,data3,data4' have four tokens each, one of which is null.

Once the beginning of a substring is found, it interprets all characters that follow as elements of the substring until it finds an end delimiter. For example, if '!' is a start delimiter and '?' is an end delimiter, the string 'abc!def?ghi!' produces the tokens: 'abc!def' and 'ghi!'. Although the exclamation point is a start delimiter, they are correctly interpreted as elements of the substring.

member.param: The string to parse.
A string that contains the start delimiter character. Pass an empty string ('') to specify the lack of a start delimiter.
A string that contains the end delimiter character. Pass an empty string ('') to specify the lack of an end delimiter.
The name of an array of substrings created from .
member.returns: the number of substrings created. Returns zero (0) if no substrings are created, or if an error occurs.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sal.TblFindNextRow(System.Windows.Forms.Control,PPJ.Runtime.SalNumber@,PPJ.Runtime.SalNumber,PPJ.Runtime.SalNumber)
member.summary: Scans forward in a table looking for a row whose flags match those specified.

remarks.para: The search stops at the first row that has any of the flags set, and none of the flags set.

Use this function in a loop to find all the table window or grid rows that match specified conditions. You do not need to increment the row number; the search continues starting at the next row. To begin the search at the first row, set to .
NOTE: You cannot use without first assigning its value to a variable. This is because is a constant, and is a receive parameter whose value the function can change.
You can specify any of the ROW* flags for and . If you want to specify more than one, combine them using the OR (|) operator.
Row Flag Constants:

member.param: The handle of the table window or grid to search.
The row at which to begin the search; the search starts on + 1. If a row is found, the row number is returned in this parameter.
The flags the row should have.
The flags the row should not have. Specify zero (0) for no flags.
member.returns: true if a row is found and false if there are no matches.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sal.TblFindPrevRow(System.Windows.Forms.Control,PPJ.Runtime.SalNumber@,PPJ.Runtime.SalNumber,PPJ.Runtime.SalNumber)
member.summary: Scans backward in a table looking for a row whose flags match those specified.

remarks.para: The search stops at the first row that has any of the flags set, and none of the flags set.

Use this function in a loop to find all the table window or grid rows that match specified conditions. You do not need to decrement the row number; the search continues starting at the next row. To begin the search at the last row, set nRow to .
Note: You cannot use without first assigning its value to a variable. This is because is a constant, and is a receive parameter whose value the function can change.
You can specify any of the ROW* flags for and . If you want to specify more than one, combine them using the OR (|) operator.
Row Flag Constants:

member.param: The handle of the table window or grid to search.
The row at which to begin the search; the search starts on + 1. If a row is found, the row number is returned in this parameter.
The flags the row should have.
The flags the row should not have. Specify zero (0) for no flags.
member.returns: true if a row is found and false if there are no matches.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sal.TblPasteRows(System.Windows.Forms.Control)
member.summary: Pastes the contents of the Clipboard to the specified table window. Assumes the Clipboard data is in text format with cells delimited by tab characters and rows delimited by end-of-line characters. Inserts the new rows into the table window without overwriting existing rows, and converts the data to the data types of the corresponding table window columns.

member.returns: true if the Clipboard contains text that is successfully inserted into the table window or grid, and false otherwise, and if none of the columns are editable.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sal.TblPopulate(System.Windows.Forms.Control,PPJ.Runtime.Sql.SalSqlHandle,PPJ.Runtime.SalString,PPJ.Runtime.SalNumber)
member.summary: Compiles, binds, and executes a SQL SELECT statement, then fetches the rows of the result set and populates a table window with them.

remarks.para: This function also works with table windows or grids that do not have columns. Columns are created at runtime based on the SQL statement's SELECT list, and the database column names are used as table window or grid column titles. If you call again during the same runtime session, the automatic table window or grid columns created by the last SELECT statement are destroyed and new columns are created.

also works with SELECT statements that do not include INTO clauses. The table window or grid must have the same number of columns as the SQL statement's SELECT list, and their data types must match the data types of the columns in the SELECT list.
If you process and Return from the message, does not fetch that row into the table window or grid. If you process but do not Return from the message, fetches the row into the table window or grid.

The message is sent before the row is actually fetched from the result set so in processing this message, you cannot refer to the row being fetched. However, the message is sent after the row is fetched, enabling you to refer to the row just fetched.

Notes on Using SalTblPopulate with the Grid: Sorting and grouping are disabled when you use or . However, sorting and grouping are subsequently re-enabled if all records are scrolled into view. always results with grouping and sorting enabled.

member.param: The name of the table window or grid to populate.
The handle of the SELECT statement. Do not use the Sql Handle passed to by other functions while the table window or grid is in use.
The SELECT statement. If the string is null (''), uses the previously prepared SELECT statement associated with . This avoids re-preparing the statement each time SalTblPopulate() executes.
How to populate the table window or grid. Specify one of these values:
member.returns: TRUE if the function succeeds and FALSE if either or is invalid.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sal.TblPopulateFromXML(System.Windows.Forms.Control,PPJ.Runtime.SalString,PPJ.Runtime.SalString,PPJ.Runtime.SalBoolean,PPJ.Runtime.SalBoolean)
member.summary: Clears a table window or grid and then fills new rows with data from an XML document. Optionally uses an XML schema to set attributes in the table.
member.remarks:
After each row of data is populated, this function sends message to the table window. If an error occurs during the read, then the data in the table may be incomplete and should not be relied upon.
When is set to true, and if the table window's columns were created at design time, the length of each column's value will be the length assigned at design time.
If the table window or grid has no design-time columns and they are being automatically created during the call to this function, then the length of each column's value will be the length that is specified in the XML schema.
This raises the possibility of truncation, if the value of an element contains more characters than are specified by the design-time length or the XML schema length.
member.param: Table window to populate.
The name of the XML document file containing data to be used to populate the table.
The name of the XML root node of the table, or the name of the XML node pertaining to a table row. See .

If true, it means that the name specified in is the actual root node of the table, and this function should use the default name "row" as the name of the node for each table row. If false, it means that the name in is actually the name of a row node, and each node found with that name should be processed as a table window or grid row.

Indicates whether to retrieve and use an XML schema for determining data types and attributes. If true, the schema is retrieved. If false, data is written into table window cells with the presumption that the table structure is already correct. Currently, cannot be specified true when is false.
member.returns: True if the function succeeds and FALSE if fails. Some failure conditions, such as an invalid file name or invalid root node name, may cause error message dialogs to be displayed.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sal.TblWriteXMLandSchema(System.Windows.Forms.Control,PPJ.Runtime.SalString,PPJ.Runtime.SalNumber)
member.summary: Writes the contents and properties of a table window to an XML file and/or a schema file.
member.remarks: If the table window contains a Date/Time column, and a cell in that column is empty, then no content will be written for that particular XML document node.
member.param: Table Window.
The path and name of the output file. Note that the schema file will have the same name, plus the suffix "_schema".
One of the XML constants(XML_DocAndSchema, XML_Document ,XML_Schema), determining whether to write XML, schema, or both.
member.returns: True if the function succeeds.

One of the XML constants(XML_DocAndSchema, XML_Document ,XML_Schema), determining whether to write XML, schema, or both.

A combination of one or more of the row flags. Rows must have these flags off in order to be part of the output to XML.

member.summary: Returns the date/time constructed from the parameters year, nMonth, nDay, nHour, minute, and nSecond.
member.remarks: If you specify invalid parameter values, an unexpected date construction can result. Note: If any of the parameter values has less than the specified number of digits, pads the resulting value with leading zeroes (0). For example, if is 92, the newly constructed date/time value. begins with 0092.
member.param: A number with a 4-digit year value. Zero is not a valid value.
A number with a 2-digit month value between 01 and 12 inclusive.
A number with a 2-digit day value between 01 and 31 inclusive.
A number with a 2-digit hour value between 0 and 23 inclusive.
A number with a 2-digit minute value between 00 and 59 inclusive.
A number with a 2-digit second value between 00 and 59 inclusive.
member.returns: the newly constructed date/time value.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sal.StartTrace(PPJ.Runtime.SalNumber,PPJ.Runtime.SalString,PPJ.Runtime.SalBoolean)
member.summary: Begins tracing. You are responsible for ensuring that existing trace log files do not grow too large.
member.remarks: Trace Constants:
member.param: One of the TRACE constants, indicating where trace output should go.
The name of the file which should contain trace information, if is .
Whether existing trace information in the output target should be cleared before the current trace operation begins.
member.returns: true if the trace was successfully initiated, false if not.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sal.EndTrace
member.summary: Stops tracing. Any calls to occurring after EndTrace() will be ignored.
member.returns: true if the function succeeds and false if it fails.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sal.Trace(PPJ.Runtime.SalNumber,PPJ.Runtime.SalString)
member.summary: Outputs a string to the trace output target.

remarks.para: Note that if tracing is not already activated, this function will return TRUE even though no trace action is taken. When writing to the event log, the severity level is kept in numeric form. When writing to any other output target, it is translated into a text string such as "Warning".

Trace() can only work in an application that previously called . So if you write an out-of-process COM server, and your COM client application calls StartTrace() before a server call, and your server calls Trace(), nothing will happen on the server side, because there was no StartTrace() in that application. In-process COM servers will not have this issue.
EVENT constants:

member.param: One of the EVENT constants, indicating level of severity.
The text of the tracing information that you wish to log.
member.returns: false if there is a write error to a data file, or if the output window exceeds maximum lines of output when writing to the output window. Returns true in all other cases.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sal.UseEventLog(PPJ.Runtime.SalBoolean,PPJ.Runtime.SalBoolean)
member.summary: Enables logging of unhandled exceptions in the event log.
member.param: Whether or not unhandled exceptions are written to the event log.
Whether the program should attempt to continue after an event is logged. Set this parameter to true for continue. Note that this parameter has no effect if is false.
member.returns: true if the function succeeds.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sal.ActiveXAutoErrorMode(PPJ.Runtime.SalBoolean)
member.summary: Turns on/off automatic COM error handling.
member.remarks: If you turn off automatic error handling, you may need to include extra logic in your application to properly decode some errors. For example, if you are using the Microsoft Rich Text control, and your application supplies an invalid file name as a property to that control, the error returned is -2146828213. In Visual Basic, the same error would return 75. To get the 75 value in SAL, convert the large negative value to hexadecimal, then extract the rightmost four hex digits (004B), then convert that value to decimal (75).
member.param: Specify false to turn off automatic error handling or specify true to turn on automatic error handling.
member.returns: This function always returns false.

member.name: M:PPJ.Runtime.Sal.ActiveXDoVerb(System.Windows.Forms.Control,PPJ.Runtime.SalNumber,PPJ.Runtime.SalBoolean)
member.summary: Perform one of the object's enumerated actions.

remarks.para: Opens an object for an operation such as editing. Each object can support its own set of verbs. The standard verbs that every object should support are listed in the table below.

entry.para: The default action for the object.
Activates the object for editing. If the application that created the object supports in place activation, the object is activated within the ActiveX container control.
Opens the object in a separate application window. If the application that created the object supports in place activation, the object is activated in its own window.
For embedded objects, hides the application that created the object.

If the user moves the focus to the ActiveX container control, creates a window for the object and prepares the object to be edited. An error occurs if the object does not support activation on a single mouse click.

If the user moves the focus to the ActiveX container control, creates a window for the object and prepares the object to be edited. An error occurs if the object does not support activation on a single mouse click.
If an object is activated for editing, discards all record of changes that the object's application can undo.

member.param: Target control on which to execute the call.
A constant that identifies the verb.
If true, sizes the object to the size of the site window upon activation.
member.returns: true if the function succeeds and false if it fails.

member.returns: true if the function succeeds and false if a valid automation dispatch could not be found.

member.name: T:PPJ.Runtime.Scripting.DynamicBinder
member.summary:
This class is a fast replacement for reflection.
Instead of using reflection to read/write fields and properties or to invoke methods, it dynamically creates IL code to directly access members.
NOTE: Methods invocation is not yet implemented.

member.summary: populated column

member.name: F:PPJ.Runtime.Sys.COL_GetID
member.summary: This table column flag indicates that you want to get a column based on its identifier. Use this constant with the Sal.TblGetColumnWindow function. 1 is the first column in the application outline.

member.name: F:PPJ.Runtime.Sys.COL_GetPos
member.summary: This table column flag indicates that you want to get a column based on its position in the table window. Use this constant with the Sal.TblGetColumnWindow function. 1 is the first (left-most) column in the table window.

member.name: F:PPJ.Runtime.Sys.COL_Editable
member.summary: This table column flag lets users edit the text of a table window column. Use this constant with the Sal.TblSetColumnFlags and Sal.TblQueryColumnFlags functions.

member.name: F:PPJ.Runtime.Sys.COL_IndicateOverflow
member.summary: This table column flag fills a table window cell with the overflow character ("#") when the text does not fit in the cell. Use this constant with the Sal.TblSetColumnFlags and Sal.TblQueryColumnFlags functions.

member.name: F:PPJ.Runtime.Sys.COL_RightJustify
member.summary: This table column flag right-justifies text in a column. If this flag is set, you cannot also set the COL_CenterJustify flag at the same time. If you set neither COL_RightJustify nor COL_CenterJustify, then left-justifies the column text by default. Use this constant with the Sal.TblSetColumnFlags and Sal.TblQueryColumnFlags functions.

member.name: F:PPJ.Runtime.Sys.COL_CenterJustify
member.summary: This table column flag indicates that you want to center text in a table window column. If this flag is set, you cannot also set the COL_CenterJustify flag at the same time. If you set neither COL_RightJustify nor COL_CenterJustify, then it left-justifies the column text by default. Use this constant with the Sal.TblSetColumnFlags and Sal.TblQueryColumnFlags functions.

member.name: F:PPJ.Runtime.Sys.COL_Selected
member.summary: This table column flag indicates that a column is selected. Use this constant with the Sal.TblSetColumnFlags and Sal.TblQueryColumnFlags functions.

member.name: F:PPJ.Runtime.Sys.COL_Visible
member.summary: This table column flag indicates that a column is visible. Use this constant with the Sal.TblSetColumnFlags and Sal.TblQueryColumnFlags functions.

member.name: F:PPJ.Runtime.Sys.COL_Invisible
member.summary: This table column flag indicates that a column is used to edit a password. Use this constant with the Sal.TblSetColumnFlags and Sal.TblQueryColumnFlags functions.

member.name: F:PPJ.Runtime.Sys.COL_DimTitle
member.summary: This table column flag indicates that a column title is show as disabled text. Use this constant with the Sal.TblSetColumnFlags and Sal.TblQueryColumnFlags functions.

member.name: F:PPJ.Runtime.Sys.COL_ReadOnly
member.summary: This table column flag indicates that the column cell is read only. Use this constant with the Sal.TblSetColumnFlags and Sal.TblQueryColumnFlags functions.

member.name: F:PPJ.Runtime.Sys.COL_UpperCase
member.summary: This table column flag indicates that the cell format is uppercase. Use this constant with the Sal.TblSetColumnFlags and Sal.TblQueryColumnFlags functions.

member.name: F:PPJ.Runtime.Sys.COL_LowerCase
member.summary: This table column flag indicates that the cell format is lowercase. Use this constant with the Sal.TblSetColumnFlags and Sal.TblQueryColumnFlags functions.

member.name: F:PPJ.Runtime.Sys.COL_MultilineCell
member.summary: This constant is used to define a column as a multi line column.

member.name: F:PPJ.Runtime.Sys.COL_EnableSort
member.summary: This grid column flag enables sorting in the context menu (right click on column header). Sorting is enabled when set to TRUE and disabled when set to FALSE. This also affects SalTblSortRows function (i.e. SalTblSortRows will have no effect if this flag is set to FALSE).

member.name: F:PPJ.Runtime.Sys.COLOR_3DFace
member.summary: The color of the window background (sometimes called the "button face" color). The default is light gray. However, a user can change the color of the window background by selecting a different color scheme. Specify this to make the color of the window background consistent with the color scheme set by the user. Use this constant with Sal.ColorGet and Sal.ColorSet.

member.name: F:PPJ.Runtime.Sys.COLOR_3DHighlight
member.summary: The color of highlighted areas. The default is white. However, the user can change the color of highlighted areas by selecting a different color scheme. Specify this to make the color of highlighted areas consistent with the color scheme set by the user. Use this constant with Sal.ColorGet and Sal.ColorSet.

member.name: F:PPJ.Runtime.Sys.COLOR_3DShadow
member.summary: The color of shadow areas. The default is dark gray. However, a user can change the color of shadow areas by selecting a different color scheme. Specify this to make the color of shadow areas consistent with the color scheme set by the user. Use this constant with Sal.ColorGet and Sal.ColorSet.

member.name: F:PPJ.Runtime.Sys.COLOR_IndexCell
member.summary: This constant refers to the cell background color of the context row in a table window column. (You cannot set the color of the cell text in the Property window). Use this constant with the Sal.ColorGet and Sal.ColorSet functions.

member.name: F:PPJ.Runtime.Sys.COLOR_IndexCellText
member.summary: This constant refers to the cell text color of the context row in a table window column. (You cannot set the color of the cell text in the Property window). Use this constant with the Sal.ColorGet and Sal.ColorSet functions.

member.name: F:PPJ.Runtime.Sys.COLOR_IndexTransparent
member.summary: This constant refers to the transparent color in a picture or push button bitmap. For example, assume you have a push button that contains a bitmap that is blue, red, and green. If you set COLOR_IndexTransparent to COLOR_Blue, the blue portions of the bitmap become transparent; this allows the color of the form window underneath the push button to show through. Use this constant with the Sal.ColorGet and Sal.ColorSet functions.

member.name: F:PPJ.Runtime.Sys.COLOR_IndexWindow
member.summary: This constant refers to the window's background color. Use this constant with the Sal.ColorGet, Sal.ColorGetSysColor, and Sal.ColorSet functions.

member.name: F:PPJ.Runtime.Sys.COLOR_IndexWindowText
member.summary: This constant refers to the window's text color. Use this constant with the Sal.ColorGet, Sal.ColorGetSysColor, and Sal.ColorSet functions.

member.name: F:PPJ.Runtime.Sys.DBP_AUTOCOMMIT
member.summary: Use this constant to either get or set the value of a database parameter indicating the current autocommit status of the database. If autocommit is on (TRUE), the database commits changes automatically after each SQL command. If autocommit is off (FALSE), then the database commits changes only when you issue a COMMIT command. Use this constant with the Sql.GetParameter, and Sql.SetParameter functions. You can only use DBP_AUTOCOMMIT with databases which support this feature. Please refer to the appropriate database manuals for more information.

member.name: F:PPJ.Runtime.Sys.DBP_BRAND
member.summary: Use this constant to obtain the brand of the database engine. Brand is represented by the numeric value of one of these constants: DBV_BRAND_ALLBASE 10 DBV_BRAND_AS400 7 DBV_BRAND_CINCOMSUPRA 20 DBV_BRAND_DB2 2 DBV_BRAND_INFORMIX 5 DBV_BRAND_INFORMIXONLINE 24 DBV_BRAND_NETWARE 6 DBV_BRAND_ORACLE 4 DBV_BRAND_ORACLE7 28 DBV_BRAND_OS2EE 3 DBV_BRAND_SQL 1 DBV_BRAND_SYBASE 8 Use this constant with the Sql.GetParameter.

member.name: F:PPJ.Runtime.Sys.DBP_FETCHTHROUGH
member.summary: Use this constant to either get or set the status of a database parameter indicating the current status of the FETCHTHROUGH feature. FETCHTHROUGH enables you to retrieve rows directly from the database server instead of from the client's input message buffer, thereby ensuring that you get the most up-to-date data. If FETCHTHROUGH is on (TRUE), the application fetches data one row at a time from the backend. Using this feature increases response time, so you should only use this feature when you need to get the most up-to-date information. If FETCHTHROUGH is off (FALSE), the application fetches data from the client's input message buffer whenever possible. This is the default. Use this constant with the Sql.GetParameter, and Sql.SetParameter, functions. You can only use this feature against SQLBase.

member.name: F:PPJ.Runtime.Sys.DBP_LOCKWAITTIMEOUT
member.summary: Use this constant to either get or set the value of a database parameter which specifies the number of seconds an application should wait for a database lock to be acquired before timing out. After the specified time has elapsed, SQLBase rolls back the transaction. The default timeout value is 300 seconds. Valid time out values are: 1-1800 Wait 1 second to 30 minutes -1 Wait forever 0 Never wait; immediately return a time out error. Use this constant with the Sql.GetParameter and Sql.SetParameter functions. You can only use this constant against databases which support the setting of lock wait timeout values. Please refer to the appropriate database manuals for more information.

member.name: F:PPJ.Runtime.Sys.DBP_NOPREBUILD
member.summary: Use this constant to either get or set the value of a database parameter which specifies whether result sets should be pre-built on remote databases when the application is in result set mode and is using the Release Locks isolation level. Pre-building a result set provides the advantages of being able to release shared locks and returning control to the client. The disadvantage of pre-building a result set is that the application must wait while the result set is being built. If NOPREBUILD is on (TRUE), result sets are not pre-built. A shared lock remains on the current page. This is the default setting. If NOPREBUILD is off (FALSE), result sets are pre-built on the remote database. Use this constant with the Sql.GetParameter and Sql.SetParameter functions. You can only use this feature against SQLBase.

member.name: F:PPJ.Runtime.Sys.DBP_ISOLEVEL
member.summary: Isolation level: RR,RL,CS,RO,SE

member.name: F:PPJ.Runtime.Sys.DBP_PRESERVE
member.summary: Use this constant to get or set the value of the database parameter that specifies whether cursor context preservation is on or off. If cursor-context preservation is on (TRUE), a COMMIT does not destroy an active result set (cursor context). This enables an application to maintain its position after a COMMIT, INSERT, or UPDATE. The cursor context is not preserved after an isolation level change. The context is preserved after a ROLLBACK if both of the following are true: The application is in the Release Locks (RL) isolation level. A DDL operation was not performed. If cursor-context preservation is off (FALSE), a COMMIT does destroy an active result set. Cursor context preservation is lost. Use this constant with the Sql.GetParameter, and Sql.SetParameter functions.

member.name: F:PPJ.Runtime.Sys.DBP_ROLLBACKONTIMEOUT
member.summary: Use this constant to either get or set the value of a database parameter which specifies the rollback status when a lock timeout occurs. If the parameter is TRUE, the entire transaction rolls back when a lock timeout occurs. If it is FALSE, only the current command rolls back on a lock timeout. Use this constant with the Sql.GetParameter, and Sql.SetParameter. The rollbackontimeout feature can only be used against some databases. Please see the appropriate database manuals for more information.

member.name: F:PPJ.Runtime.Sys.DBP_VERSION
member.summary: Use this constant to get the version number of the server software. Use this constant with the Sql.GetParameter function.

member.name: F:PPJ.Runtime.Sys.SQLERROR_Reason

member.name: F:PPJ.Runtime.Sys.SQLERROR_Remedy
member.summary: When calling Sql.ErrorText, set the nType parameter to this constant to retrieve the error remedy.
